content.webTitle: Dutton defends raids while Labor challenges Coalition over press freedom

fields.headline: Dutton defends raids while Labor challenges Coalition over press freedom
fields.bodyText: The home affairs minister, Peter Dutton, has defended two police raids on media organisations while Labor has challenged the government to show leadership on press freedom and defend the public’s right to know. On Friday morning an interview on Channel Nine’s Today descended into a slanging match, with the home affairs minister accusing Labor of attacking the Australian federal police’s investigations while the new Labor leader, Anthony Albanese, accused Dutton of epitomising “secrecy and a lack of scrutiny”. Raids on the the ABC and News Corp Australia’s Annika Smethurst and possible charges for reproduction of secret documents in their reports on alleged unlawful killings by Australian troops in Afghanistan and plans to extend powers to spy on Australian citizens have set off a firestorm about media freedom. While Labor’s shadow home affairs minister, Kristina Keneally, has called for a bipartisan review of national security laws and Scott Morrison has said he is “open to discussing” concerns about the raids, Dutton moved to head off any debate about changing the laws. “If we strip it down we are talking about highly classified documents,” he told Today. “The laws that apply today are the same laws that [would have] applied under the Shorten government or [applied under the] Rudd government or Howard government in relation to the leaking of documents.” Dutton said the idea there would be “no penalty” for publishing top secret documents “would go against tradition in this country that would span back decades, and the same around the world”. “I’m concerned that if people are leaking top secret documents, that that can affect our national security.” The home affairs minister said the AFP had an obligation to investigate the matters after they were referred by the secretary of the defence department and the director general of the Australian Signals Directorate. Dutton said it was “quite unfair” for Labor to criticise AFP officers, prompting Albanese to correct him, that he was “targeting the government”. Albanese said it was true “these are old laws” but “Australians are concerned that media’s capacity to scrutinise government is under threat”. Dutton demanded Albanese apologise, which he refused to do. “You characterise secrecy and a lack of scrutiny that embodies your entire political career,” Albanese replied. Later, at the declaration of his election in Grayndler, Albanese told reporters that freedom of the press is “fundamental to democracy”. “Mr Morrison and Mr Dutton have to say exactly what their position is on freedom of the press. “At the moment they’re silent about it – they pretend it’s nothing to do with them and there’s nothing to see here.” Asked about changes to legislation, Albanese said it would be “a start” for Morrison to acknowledge there is an issue which is “disturbing”. “Annika Smethurst is a professional journalist … who told Australians that there were proposals being considered that would cause concern for all those worried about the privacy of Australian citizens. “I think it’s a good thing that was reported, frankly, because Australians do have a right to know what is going in a democracy.” Earlier, Dutton said there were “no proposals” to extend spying powers, claiming the issue had been “wrongly reported” and debate could have occurred when legislation was presented “around whatever the proposal might be”. On Thursday the acting AFP commissioner, Neil Gaughan, attempted to contain the growing political fallout by denying suggestions the police had waited until after the federal election to execute warrants and claiming no contact had been made with the executive since they informed Dutton’s office when the investigations started. The Liberal MP Craig Kelly, who chairs parliament’s joint committee on law enforcement, has said the AFP will be called to explain its decision as “the first order of business” once MPs returned to Canberra in July. The Labor senator Doug Cameron has called for a new standing committee to scrutinise AFP and security agencies’ operations, while the Greens and Centre Alliance have called for freedom of the press to be enshrined in a charter of rights or the constitution.
